Everyone is hunkering down and attempting to weather the storm together. And I am confident we will get through this together, but it has made me change the way we are running this campaign. In times like these, we think of family. And the coronavirus outbreak has had an outsized effect on our campaign team. We have staff from all over the country who have moved to Kentucky to help us win this race. They all have families who are concerned about their well being. We have to take care of them. No longer can we hold town halls and meet-and-greets. Our staff is now working from home. The entire setup of our campaign has adapted to fit this new world order. In a period like this, when the country is undergoing such a crisis, and people are in survival mode, the question arises: should we keep running this race? And the answer is, absolutely, yes. We must. For me and Lynn, this pandemic has only strengthened our resolve. It has only deepened our dedication to the critical mission of defeating Mitch McConnell. Here’s why. When Donald Trump was elected, there was one man with the power to check his authority: Mitch McConnell. Mitch McConnell decided it was worth risking an incompetent executive like Donald Trump — in order to get far-right conservative judges on the bench and corporate tax cuts signed into law. Mitch McConnell decided it was worth risking our national security and our democracy — just to notch partisan victories for corporate interests and the Republican Party. Mitch McConnell decided we could survive an incompetent President and incompetent administration. Well, this outbreak proves one thing: Mitch was dead wrong. Because Mitch put party over country, the coronavirus has spread farther and faster than it ever should have. Tests were not available when they should have been. Information has been dispensed inconsistently and inaccurately.  And now we are paying the price. We all are paying the price. Mitch chose his political power over us, and now Kentuckians will die as a result. But instead of working to save lives, Mitch fled Washington for a three-day weekend — just to take Brett Kavanaugh around to fancy political dinners in Louisville. We can’t count on Mitch. We can’t elect someone like him ever again. He must be replaced with someone who actually cares about us. That’s why I’m fighting harder than ever to win this race. But, for us to win, we need the funding to compete in the Democratic primary and the general election. Now, it feels wrong to fundraise during a period of crisis like this — but after long hard thought, I realized that this mission is not just about surviving Coronavirus, but preventing the next crisis. And to do that, we must take down Mitch McConnell. We cannot give in. To give in during a crisis like this would be to let Mitch win. I can’t do that. We can’t do that. So, to those of you who are in a position where you are able to contribute, I ask that you give whatever you can to this mission to help us beat Mitch McConnell. The place to do that is at MikeForKY.com/donate We’re setting an ambitious but necessary goal of raising $500K by the official FEC filing deadline on March 31st. That’s an aggressive goal, but we believe we can do it, together. Please consider donating at MikeForKY.com/donate To those of you who are not in a position to contribute during this time, I completely understand. Know that you are no less of a supporter, no less a member of this team. You are just as important as anyone else in our mission to defeat Mitch McConnell. Military exercises in the Republic of Korea are not “ridiculous,” despite the President’s recent comments, and I’d argue are critical for a successful deterrence to North Korea aggression.  I participated in exercises in the ROK throughout the 80’s and in 2000 started a two-year assignment in Seoul as the Marine Forces Korea war planner (MARFORK-ACS G5) and keenly appreciate the challenges of defending a country whose capitol and it’s 13-million citizens are within artillery and rocket range of a blood thirsty and vicious regime. First and foremost, we need to understand that the defense of the ROK is unlike any other US military partnership. It is not a US-led coalition with our South Korean allies playing a subordinate role; it is a full-on partnership with the ROK bearing most of the burden in lives and treasure. Our ROK allies are earnest and selfless and will bear a disproportionate burden in blood if the President’s ill-considered words embolden the North Korean dictator to attack. Effective coordination in a complex battlespace across language and cultural divides requires constant tending and exercising command and control, mobilization and deployment of forces are critical for success.  Though it’s fallen into fashion lately to exonerate him, Dean Acheson address to the National Press Club in 1949 failed to include South Korea in a list of our defensive priorities in the far Pacific; six months later, North Korea attacked. The signaling the president is now engaged in is far less nuanced than Acheson’s and, considering his outspoken affection for the North Korean dictator, dangerous to a great friend and ally.  I’ll leave you with this thought. The day after 9-11, I exited work after 24-hours of trying to assess the impact on the peninsula of the attacks on US soil to find that the ROK Marine Corps had placed a physical barrier between the MARFORK headquarters and the adjacent road.  Our HQ was literally within spitting distance of a main thoroughfare through the capitol and ROK Marines had, unsolicited, lined that wall with their bodies and armored vehicles. Placed themselves physically between we who worked unknowingly behind a brick wall and some as yet unknown threat. Those young Korean Marines stood a lonely vigil throughout the long winter that followed without complaint or recognition. That, to me, is a worthy ally and friend.
